required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Massage on Hamstring Muscle Soreness
clinical_study.official_title: Danish: Integreret Motion p√• Arbejdspladsen (IRMA) English: Implementation of Exercise at the Workplace

lead_sponsor.agency: National Research Centre for the Working Environment, Denmark

clinical_study.source: National Research Centre for the Working Environment, Denmark

brief_summary.textblock: Delayed onset muscular soreness peaks in 24-48 hours after unaccustomed strenuous physical exercise. Therapists often provide manual massage with the hands to acutely relief the soreness. Alternatives to manual hand massage can be useful for therapists. Here the investigators examine the acute effect of a "massage roller" on DOMS in the hamstring muscles

primary_outcome.measure: Perceived soreness on a scale of 0-10
primary_outcome.time_frame: change from before to after massage (average of 0, 10, 30 and 60 min after)

secondary_outcome.measure: Pressure pain threshold (PPT) of the hamstring muscles
secondary_outcome.time_frame: change from before to after massage (average of 0, 10, 30 and 60 min after)
change from before to after massage (average of 0, 10, 30 and 60 min after)

arm_group.description: Control group, does not receive any intervention

Massage will be performed on the left or right hamstring muscle (randomized) for ten minutes with a massage roller. The contralateral leg will not be massaged, but serve as a non-massaged control leg to assess possible cross-over effects from the massaged leg

intervention.description: The hamstring muscle will be massaged with a "massage roller" for ten minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- working age adults
Exclusion Criteria:
- blood pressure above 160/100
- disease of the cervical spine

facility.name: National Research Centre for the Working Environment

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: National Research Centre for the Working Environment, Denmark
